import React from 'react' import { mdx } from '@mdx-js/react' /* @jsx mdx */ import BlogMeta from "../components/BlogMeta"; export const meta = { title: "Next.js MDX Blog Kit", tags: ["Next.js", "MDX"], layout: "post", publishDate: "2011-01-01", modifiedDate: false, seoDescription: "This is the home page." }; const makeShortcode = name => function MDXDefaultShortcode(props) { console.warn("Component " + name + " was not imported, exported, or provided by MDXProvider as global scope") return
}; const layoutProps = { meta }; const MDXLayout = "wrapper" export default function MDXContent({ components, ...props }) { return

{`Pedro Bazzo`}

{`Blog kit about React.js development and the programming world`}

{`Check out the `}{`docs`}

{`Feature List:`}

  • {`Why React `}
  • {`How to start an application with React`}
  • {`What is JSX for`}
  • {`What is Virtual DOM`}
  • {`How React components lifecycle works`}
  • {`The Age of Componentization`}
  • {`One-way data binding`}
  • {`Flux, Redux ou MobX`}
  • {`What to use to create unit tests with React`}

{`** Introduction To begin, we need to know what React is. For this, nothing better than using the definition of who created it, Facebook itself, which defines it like this: A declarative, efficient and flexible JavaScript library for creating visual interfaces With that, we have to: React is not a framework, but a library. React is used to create visual interfaces (UI). These two pieces of information together create the first big confusion for those just starting out: if React is just a library and only serves to create UI, how can I create complete applications with it? And to resolve this issue we need to understand that when the community refers to React, what it really means is React and its ecosystem. And this ecosystem is formed by: React JSX ES2015 Webpack Flux / Redux axios / fetch Jest / Mocha And with all these items, which are part of the React ecosystem, we can say that it is possible to create complete applications using React. JSX Explaining quickly, JSX is an extension of JavaScript syntax (hence the name, JavaScript Syntax eXtension) that allows us to write HTML within JavaScript. In the early days, JSX was a major reason for criticism and jokes about React. In theory we were back in time when mixing HTML with JavaScript. The staunchest critics claimed that JSX breaks one of the basic principles of software development, which is the Separation of Concerns. In my opinion, this view is wrong for two reasons:`}

{`React itself, the library and not the ecosystem, as I mentioned earlier, represents only the part of your application's view. So, by definition, it has only one concern: rendering the UI. So which concerns are being violated? And even if JSX violated this principle, the technology area evolves (and a lot) over time. If one of the principles that we have always held true does not make sense for a given scenario, should we still force ourselves to follow that principle? Regardless of my personal opinions, over time the community realized that JSX was the right decision and that it ended up becoming one of the great foundations of React's success. Components As previously stated, React's main function is to assist in the creation of the UI. I just left one important detail out: React uses components, and only components, so that it is possible to increase the maximum reuse in your application.`}
